case_vignette: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after coughing up copious amounts of blood-tinged sputum at his nursing home. He recently had an upper respiratory tract infection that was treated with antibiotics. He has a long-standing history of productive cough that has worsened since he had a stroke 3 years ago. He smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years until the stroke, after which he quit. The patient appears distressed and short of breath. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Physical examination shows digital clubbing and cyanosis of the lips. Coarse crackles are heard in the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows increased translucency and tram-track opacities in the right lower lung field.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.

Are you currently taking any medications for your breathing or lung problems?
I'm sorry, but I don't have the knowledge to answer that question.
Do you have a family history of lung cancer or any other lung diseases?
I'm sorry, but I don't have the knowledge to answer that question.
**Final Diagnosis:** Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with hemoptysis due to smoking history
